If I see earnings are going to beat estimates by a wide margin, I know the stock will pop. That’s when I quietly buy call options or accumulate shares through a shell account to avoid detection. The key is to act before the market reacts. 

If the report shows trouble—like a sharp drop in margins or a pending lawsuit—I’d short the stock or sell off my existing position. I always hedge with inverse ETFs or futures to lock in gains. The real art is blending these moves with legitimate trades so the patterns don’t stand out. 

I also watch for subtle signals: management tone, guidance changes, or off-balance-sheet liabilities. Sometimes the footnotes in the 10-Q hint at bigger issues. If I spot a trend, I’ll layer in positions over time to avoid triggering red flags. 

The hardest part is resisting the urge to overreach. I stick to low-risk, high-probability plays—like sector rotation based on earnings momentum. Greed is a liability. The goal isn’t to get rich quick; it’s to stay under the radar for years. That’s how you compound.
